content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here is how you can implement this function using regular expressions: ```julia using Markdown function q_and_a_extractor(md) # Parse markdown to HTML html = Markdown.parse(md) |> x -> join(x, "") |> s -> replace(s, "\n" => " ") # Extract text in the sections Question and Answer using regular expressions q_and_a = capture_all(r"

(.*?)<\/h1>(.*?)

.*?<\/h1>", html) question, answer = "", "" if length(q_and_a) == 2 # If the markdown has both Question and Answer sections q_and_a[1] = replace(q_and_a[1], "

" => "") q_and_a[1] = replace(q_and_a[1], "

" => "") question = strip(replace(q_and_a[1], " " => "")) q_and_a[2] = replace(q_and_a[2], "

" => "") q_and_a[2] = replace(q_and_a[2], "

" => "") answer = strip(replace(q_and_a[2], " " => "")) end return (question, answer) end # Example usage: md = """ # Question This is a question. # Answer This is an answer. """ @show q_and_a_extractor(md) # returns ("This is a question.", "This is an answer.") ``` This function parses the markdown into HTML first, because the regular expressions used to capture Question and Answer sections are designed for HTML format. The `capture_all` function finds all occurrences of the specified pattern in the given string. Note that this solution assumes that there will be exactly one set of "# Question" and "# Answer", and also assumes that there won't be nested sections (like a subsection within an answer). If your markdown has multiple sets of questions or answers, you would need to adjust the function accordingly.
